International Tuition: $18,015.00

School: Angelo DelZotto School of Construction Management

Context:
The Angelo DelZotto School of Construction Management offers a construction technology program with field education and experiential learning opportunities. Graduates can enter various careers in the construction industry such as construction technicians, site managers, project and construction managers, estimators, home builders, general contractors, building and home inspectors, and technical sales agents. They may also start their own businesses. The construction industry generates over 360,000 jobs and pays more than $22 billion in wages in Ontario alone. In Toronto, there is a high demand for housing due to population growth and expanding transit networks, leading to significant construction activity. The School of Construction Management has an active Program Advisory Committee that contributes ideas and opinions on curriculum changes and industry trends. Students can continue to the third year of the Construction Engineering Technology Program for an Advanced Diploma or transfer to the Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) degree program after completing three years in the construction technology program, with a minimum GPA of 3.0 required.

Required courses for semester 1 include BLDG 1025 - Surveying for Construction Technology, BLDG 1042 - Construction Materials Methods 1, BLDG 1126 - Print and Specifications Reading for Construction Technology 1, and BLDG 1127 - Construction Management 1. However, please note that the program is undergoing current review and courses after year 1 are expected to change in the 2023-24 year. For more information, see the Transfer Guide.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Construction Engineering Technician Program T161 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
Semesters and Courses:
- Semester 1: BLDG 1127 (Construction Management 1 - Introduction and Overview), BLDG 1128 (AutoCad for Construction Technology), COMM 2000 (Communicating Across Contexts), MATH 1140 (Mathematics for Construction Technology 1), GNED (General Education Elective)
- Semester 2: BLDG 1073 (Construction Materials Laboratory), BLDG 1077 (Construction Health and Safety), BLDG 1078 (Revit for Construction Technology), BLDG 1129 (Construction Estimating 1), BLDG 1136 (Print and Specifications Reading for Construction Technology 2), BLDG 1145 (Construction Materials and Methods 2), BLDG 1165 (Introduction to Building Science), MATH 1150 (Mathematics for Construction Technology 2)
- Semester 3: BLDG 1076 (Building Code 1), BLDG 2019 (Construction Estimating 2), BLDG 2021 (Construction Management 2 – Planning and Scheduling), BLDG 2061 (Statics), BLDG 2090 (Principles of Construction Law), BLGD 3060 (Applied Building Science), COMM 1113 (Professional Communications for Building Technologies), GNED (General Education Elective)
- Semester 4: BLDG 2045 (Construction Management 3 – Site Operations), BLGD 2046 (Mechanical and Electrical Installations), BLGD 2065 (Strength of Materials), BLGD 2068 (Workplace Skills for Construction Technology), BLGD 2076 (Building Code 2), BLGD 3004 (Pricing Construction Works), GNED (General Education Elective)

Important Notes:
- It is recommended to take COMM 1000 before progressing to COMM 2000 based on the results of placement test. This course does not count as a course required for graduation and will be charged extra.

Program Learning Outcomes:
The graduate demonstrates the ability to:
- Develop and use strategies to enhance professional growth and ongoing learning in the construction engineering field.
- Comply with workplace health and safety practices and procedures in accordance with current legislation and regulations.
- Complete duties in compliance with contractual obligations, applicable laws, standards, bylaws, codes and ethical practices in the construction engineering field.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Construction Engineering Technician Program T161 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The text provides information about the obligations, responsibilities, and tasks for individuals in the construction engineering field. Some of these include carrying out sustainability practices, collaborating with stakeholders, collecting and interpreting technical data, using industry-specific technologies, assisting in scheduling and monitoring construction projects, preparing estimates, performing quality control testing, and applying teamwork and leadership skills. The text also includes tuition fees for domestic and international students, as well as additional costs and financial assistance information.

FACTUAL INFORMATION:
- Obligations and responsibilities in construction engineering field: sustainability practices, collaboration with stakeholders, collecting and interpreting technical data, using industry-specific technologies, scheduling and monitoring projects, preparing estimates, performing quality control testing, teamwork and leadership skills.
- Tuition fees for first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2023: Domestic - $3,978.00, International - $18,015.00.
- Additional costs (subject to change): not explicitly stated in the text.
- Financial assistance information: OSAP funding is available for eligible applicants.
- Note: fees are subject to board approval and change without notice.
- Disclaimer: information contained in the website is subject to change without notice, should not be viewed as a representation or warranty, students are responsible for verifying the information.

Context:
George Brown College requires the following admission requirements for applicants:
- Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent
- grade 12 English (C or U)
- grade 11 Math (M or U) or grade 12 (C or U)
- Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English and Math, OR may consider upgrading to achieve the credit(s) needed in English and Math.

Minimum course exemptions can be achieved through college or university credits. More information can be found on the Transfer Guide page.

International Students should refer to the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.

The Angelo DelZotto School of Construction Management strongly recommends that students own or purchase a laptop and arrange for home internet service with 25 to 40 Mbps and a ping time of 20–100 ms. The laptop specifications should meet or exceed the following specifications:
- operating system: Windows 10 Home 64-bit English
- processor: 9th Generation Intel® Core™ i7-9750H (12MB Cache, up to 4.5 GHz, 6 cores)
- memory (RAM): 16GB (2x8GB DDR4 2666MHz)
- disk space: 256GB M.2 PCIe NVMe Solid State Drive (Boot) + 1TB 5400 rpm 2.5" SATA Hard Drive (Storage)
- display card: NVIDIA® GeForce RTX™ 2060 6GB GDDR6
- connectivity: 802.11ac WiFi and Bluetooth, 2 x 2 ports: 1x HDMI 2.0; 3x SuperSpeed USB 3.1 Gen 1 Type-A including 1x with PowerShare; 1x 2-in-1 SD / MicroMedia Card slot; 1x Wedge lock slot
- screen size: minimum 15.6 inch FHD(1920 x 1080) 300nits IPS Anti-Glare.

George Brown College does not guarantee admission to a program with minimum requirements met. Applicants may be required to have grades higher than the minimum stated. Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English and Math or consider upgrading to achieve the credits needed in English and Math. International Students should refer to the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements. Course exemptions can be achieved through college or university credits, more information on this can be found on the Transfer Guide page.
